title: How do gravitational forces act on Earth? - Quora

response.answer_text: How do gravitational forces act on Earth? Our best theory of gravity is the General Theory of Relativity. You will recall that in the Theory of Special Relativity we noticed that at high speeds, (speeds approaching the speed of light), time slows and length contracts. Remember that we can also analyze speed as kinetic energy, therefore we might say that Special Relativity says that at high kinetic energies time slows and space contracts. We also know that mass and energy are related through E=m*c^2. So if energy (in the form of kinetic energy) causes time to slow and space to contract, then we should not be surprised to find that mass (which is after all another form of energy) also causes space to contract and time to dilate. Further if space contracts and time dilates due to mass, it seems appropriate to say that spacetime warps due to the proximity of mass. Gravity then might be described as an object following the straightest possible line through spacetime. According to Newtonian mechanics, an object continuing along a straight line with no force feels no acceleration. The feeling of no acceleration is exactly the feeling during free fall, following the geodesic path through spacetime. But the frame of reference to which we are relating (the surface of the Earth) is in close approximation a Euclidean spacetime (Earth as a globe is true but only a much larger scale). In Newtonian terms (every object will remain in uniform motion in a straight line unless compelled to change its state by the action of an external force) our deviation from the “straight” geodesic line prescribed by curved spacetime is the “force” we feel as gravity.

There is no explanation for gravity other than it exists.

This particle attracts other gravitons and has no repulsive force hence any two bodies, however far will apply gravitational pull towards each other!
